none: Letter to Mrs. McInnis from M. Scott, June 22, 1890
Letter to Mrs. McInnis from M. Scott, June 22, 1890
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]

L. A. SCOTT,

Melissa, Texas, June 22nd 1890
Belmont Farm.

Mrs. McInnis
My Very dear Friend

I am always
so sorry when you feel troubled, We
know nothing of what has taken place
since Thomas & Willie left. except what
you wrote me. but its enough to
know that Mr. McInnis is going away
and that you are feeling troubled, not
perhaps that he is going to leave there
but that he has been treated unjust
ly, which I have no doubt but that
the Board has done. for it would
be in keeping with some of their other
work. But let their work be what it
may, Mr. McInnis will leave there with
a good name, it is untarnished, and
he is young, with good business
capacity, and industry and energy

**Comprehensive Analysis of a Handwritten Letter** Alright, let's break this down. My task is to transcribe this letter as accurately as possible, taking into account the formatting and any corrections made by the writer. First, the image itself: the header "L. A. SCOTT" is printed clearly at the top left. The date and location, "Melissa, Texas, June 22nd 1890," are handwritten. The "22nd" is interesting; the "2"s are loopy, and it could be misread, but the context and the superscript "nd" confirm it. Below the date is "Belmont Farm," also handwritten. Then comes the salutation: "Mrs. McInnis / My Very dear Friend." Now, for the body of the letter. This is where it gets interesting and requires closer inspection to maintain the intended meaning. I note the line breaks; I must preserve those. I'll take it line by line: "I am always / so sorry when you feel troubled, We / know nothing of what has taken place / since Thomas & Willie left. except what / you wrote me. but its enough to". The "its" here is crucial because, while it could be "tis", the formation of the "t" suggests "its". Next, "know that [crossed out: you] Mr. McInnis is going away". This is a key correction. The word "you" has been crossed out and "Mr. McInnis" written above with a caret. The "you" is essentially deleted so I'm transcribing it as if only the correction is present. So, I will mark this to show the correction. Then we have, "and that you are feeling troubled, not / perhaps that he is going to leave there / but that he has been treated unjust / ly, which I have no doubt but that / the Board has done. for it would / be in keeping with some of their other / work. But let their work be what it / may, Mr. McInnis will leave there with / a good name, it is untarnished, and / he is young, with good business / capacity, and industry and energy". The word "untarnished" has been underlined for emphasis so, for clarity, I will transcribe with italics to preserve that nuance. I will make a note of this. The overall goal is to present a literal transcription preserving the original form with as much fidelity to the original as possible.

to make his way in the world.
Do not trouble my dear, you have
no cause for anxiety, perhaps leaving
there will be much the best for
you both in a short time. I
hope for a more pleasant life for
both of you. I have often heard
Thomas say that [crossed-out] Mc Innis was
so eminently fitted for the Banking
business, and other things where he
would be his own master.

We had such a good S.S. lesson to
day. when studying it I thought of you
and hoped you too. would study
it, and take the lesson to your own
heart, and let it do you good.
"Trust in our Heavenly Father". I have
so needed the lesson. and in trying
to impress it upon the young men of
my class. it went to my own heart.
and I trust has made the way clearer
and my trust greater, and stronger
and doubts will come no more.

[Inverted text at top:]
Till Prof Mc Innis to advise me [?]
of Boards action in my direction

[Left Margin:]
Mamma sends love to both

**Transcription Process for Handwritten Letter** Alright, let's break this down. The task is clear: transcribe this handwritten letter image, preserving its original form while adhering to specific guidelines. We're dealing with a text from the 19th or early 20th century, judging by the script's Spencerian-esque style and paper quality. The output should be a straightforward transcription, respecting line breaks and any structural elements, like paragraphs and marginalia. Initially, I scan the image, noting the cursive script's rightward slant and its relative legibility. The handwriting presents certain peculiarities in letter formations, such as the way "t"s are crossed, and "s"s are formed. The prompt requires us to transcribe *all* text. There's cross-writing at the top—upside-down and potentially from a different page, or it may be a postscript. The prompt says "all text", so I need to account for this. The inverted text appears like marginalia, which means I'll handle it accordingly—logically inserting it, or transcribing it at the end. After examination, the inverted text seems like a continuation or postscript. Next, I do a line-by-line transcription of the main body. I start by transcribing each line of the main text, noting individual letter formations and possible corrections. I encounter a crossed-out word in line 8: "Thomas say that [crossed-out] Mc Innis was". The crossed-out word looks like "Rev", but the image quality makes it challenging. I must stay true to the visual state, so I'll mark the illegible characters with a descriptive bracketed label. The upside-down text reads: "of Board's action in my direction" and "Till Prof McInnis & advise me [?]". I will transcribe this text also, and place this at the end, considering its location as possible marginalia. While transcribing the text, I note potential details of the document: the "S.S." acronym, the use of quotation marks, and ink smudges, and the capitalizations used in the text. I make every effort to read the text in its original form. There's also vertically written text in the left margin. It's legible: "Mamma sends love to both". Returning to the inverted text, I interpret the last word. I determine it's likely "Copy". It matches the context of the boards' actions. The margin text, "Mamma sends love to both", will be at the end, indicated as margin text. Finally, I format the text as instructed, preserving line breaks with HTML tags. The paragraphs will use `

`, and line breaks within the paragraphs will use `
`. The formatting is straightforward. One final check on the inverted text: "Till Prof Mc Innis to advise me [illegible]" with [?] for the unclear text. The final transcription will include the main body, the inverted text, and the margin text. And that's about it.

[Margin (top, inverted): Kindest love from Sister] L. A. SCOTT, [1890, June 22] Melissa, Texas, ____________________ 189 We have not heard if the Board has found any fault with Willie but if yours and Mrs. Gully's family are gone, I do not thing he will care to go back there, and I am sure Nellie will be very much opposed to it. and if they do not go back. And you gone, I will never have the least inclination to see the place again. It was gratifying to know how the boys received Thom us, and the respect shown him by others, — but it has not taken away all the sting, but I do [illegible] talk about it now. and the thoughts will quit coming after a while. I would love to have seen your Father and Mother again. And your dear little ones, oh! I can't bear to think I will never see you and them again. but I will hope that

**My Transcription Journey**

Okay, here we go. The user wants me to render this handwritten letter into plain text. I see a letter with some interesting features. First, a printed header "L.A. SCOTT," and a pencil annotation "[1890, June 22]" – that's the date, I assume. There's also some text upside down at the top: "[Margin (top, inverted): Kindest love from Sister]". I'll be sure to indicate that. The letter starts with "Melissa, Texas, ____________________ 189_". There's no handwritten date in the blank.

Now, into the handwriting. It's cursive, a bit slanted. The first line: "We have not heard if the Board..." Aha, that first word. The handwriting. The writer clearly writes an 'a' very open. I have to figure out what that first word is: "Bourie"? "Board"? Context suggests it has to do with some kind of "Board". I think the 'd' is looped, but the handwriting is strange. I will transcribe it as "Board", hoping it makes sense.

Line 4: "I do not thing". Hmm, "thing" instead of "think". I will transcribe what's written: "thing".

Line 11: "to know how the boys received..." Ah, here's a tricky one. The word in the image, ends on line 11 and the rest continues on line 12. "Thom" / "us". What is this? Looking closely. It looks like it is split in two, it has to be part of a name. After the word "Them", the beginning of line 12 is "...us, and...". I could also see it being "him", with an elongated ascender. But the grammar doesn't make sense if it's "him". I will transcribe it as "Thom" / "us". Context suggests the word must be "Thomas". It's a slightly odd way to write it but seems like what is written. So this will have a line break mid-word.

Also, it looks like a hole or ink blot in line 14: "all the sting, but I do [illegible] talk". It looks like I cannot recover the missing word. Let's see if I can find what it should be. It makes sense that the word would be "not". The sentence says, "...but it has not taken away all the sting, but I do [not] talk about it now". I will just use `[illegible]`.

Now, time to get this done. I will put together the transcription according to my plan and the guidelines. I will be sure to mark the pencil annotations and the upside-down text. The rest of the transcription seems to be quite clear, but I’ve double-checked those tough bits to make sure everything's correct. I will put together the transcription and finish it.

some time we will have you & Mr Innis
and the dear children all at our
own home. When we can look
back to this time that now seems
grievous and say "it was all for
the best." When ever the times
comes that you can come, just
know that you will make us
glad by coming.
I know you will be kept busy
until you leave. but I will be so
glad to have you write again
We are so glad to have little
Mulcombs picture. it is so good
kiss the dear little ones and sometime
tell [them] of us.
May God bless you, and give you
strength to bear your coming trial
and May you Trust our Heavenly
Father and all will be well with
you. dear love for your Mother and
Mr. Innis. and your dear self from
Thomas and. Your affectionate friend
M. Scott.

**The Transcriptionist's Mindset** Okay, here's the deal. I've got this image, likely an old handwritten letter, and my job is to get that text down, *precisely*. I'm a professional; accuracy is key. I've got a set of rules – gotta preserve original spelling, punctuation, and even handwriting quirks, and I need to format it with these specific HTML tags. No autocorrecting or interpreting *too* much, just what is on the page. First, I start by *really* looking at the image. It's cursive, which means some letters are gonna need some serious deciphering. It's probably from the late 19th or early 20th century. I need to make sure I get it right, down to the details. Alright, step-by-step it is. First line, "some time we will [have] you & Mr Innis." "Mr Innis" is the name, it looks good, common last name, it appears again later. I've checked the "have" – it's inserted, so a `sup` tag it is. Next line, "and the dear children..." "and" is written as "anu"– handwriting style, where 'd' looks like 'u'. I need to decide, do I transcribe it exactly? I will stay with "and" unless it's a clear misspelling, and this is just the style of that writer. I'll stay consistent. Going on, "glad by coming." Looks like "glue" in the cursive, a lot like it... but does "make us glue" make sense? No. The *context* screams "glad." I'll use it every time it appears, even if the "d" isn't quite right. Preservation of intent vs. a strict rendition of the stroke. This "little Malcombs picture", I see "Mulcombs" (Malcom's), and the writer is inconsistent with 'a' versus 'u'. Given the instructions about preserving spelling, let me go with "Mulcombs." Later, "May God bless you..." Wait... "God" looks like "You" in the cursive! But the sentence makes no sense as "You." I am going to stick with "God," making some kind of allowance for the handwriting's appearance. It has to be God, because the sentence needs to make sense. Next, "strength to bear your coming trial." "Trial" looks like "triue" or "time." I see some looped letters. Contextually, "trial" fits best with "strength to bear." Let's stick with "trial." Now, let's format this correctly. Using `p` for the paragraph, `br` for line breaks, `sup` for the inserted "have," and I'll keep the "[them]" tag for that obscured word on line 16. The final text: ```html

some time we will have you & Mr Innis
and the dear children all at our
own home. When we can look
back to this time that now seems
grievous and say "it was all for
the best." When ever the times
comes that you can come, just
know that you will make us
glad by coming.
I know you will be kept busy
until you leave. but I will be so
glad to have you write again
We are so glad to have little
Mulcombs picture. it is so good
kiss the dear little ones and sometime
tell [them] of us.
May God bless you, and give you
strength to bear your coming trial
and May you Trust our Heavenly
Father and all will be well with
you. dear love for your Mother and
Mr. Innis. and your dear self from
Thomas and. Your affectionate friend
M. Scott.
